sen.j: 大幾（だいき）は日本の戦国時代 (日本)、安土桃山時代の人物。
sen.e: Daiki lived in Sengoku Period (in Japan) and Azuchi-Momoyama Period.

sen.e: Daiki was a Buddhism priest of Rinzai-shu faction.

sen.j: 織田信長と豊臣秀吉の信認を得て、そのブレーンとして活躍した。
sen.e: Daiki obtained confidence of Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and played important roles for them as a member of their brains.
He obtained the trust of both Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and played important roles as a think tank for both individuals.

sen.j: 備中国下道郡久代村横田（現在の岡山県総社市久代）に生まれ、幼少時に地元・久代村横田の天福寺（天福禅寺）で小僧となる。
sen.e: Daiki was born in Yokota in Hisashiro village in Shimomichi county in Bicchu Province (currenly, Hisashiro in Fusashiro City in Okayama Prefecture) and, wihen he was a child, became a young Buddhism monk in Tenpuku-ji temple (Tempukuzen-ji temple) in his home town, Yokota in Hisashiro village.

sen.j: 天正9年（1581年）2月に織田信長の使者として備中国経山城主中島元行に使いをし、信長方への加勢を要請。
sen.e: In February 1581, Daiki brought a message to Motoyuki NAKAJIMA, the lord of Tsuneyama-jo castle in Bicchu Province as a messenger of Nobunaga ODA and demanded reinforcements for Nobunaga's army.

sen.j: 信長の死後は秀吉に仕え活躍する。
sen.e: After Nobunaga died, Daiki served Hideyoshi playing an important role.
After Nobunaga died, Daiki played an important role while serving Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 秀吉の要請によって朝鮮に渡り、当地の人情、風俗などを調査し、文禄・慶長の役に参画する。
sen.e: Daiki went to Korea by request of Hideyoshi, surveyed on the human nature, customs, etc., of Korea, and participated Bunroku War and Keicho War.

sen.j: その後、豊臣秀頼の養育係を依頼され、その任に付くが、しばらくして、建仁寺の文英清韓を代役として推挙して地元に帰郷。
sen.e: After that, Daiki was asked to be the nursing tutor of Hideyori TOYOTOMI and accepted the position, however, after a while, he recommended Seikan BUNEI of Kennin-ji temple as his substitute and returned to his home town.

sen.j: 宝福寺満足庵の住職となり、久代村横田才の鼻にて示寂した。
sen.e: Daiki became the chief priest of Manzoku-an hermitage of Hofuku-ji temple and died in front of a wise man in Yokota in Hisashiro village.

sen.j: 天福寺に墓と石碑がある。
sen.e: Daiki's grave and a stone monument for him were in Tenpulu-ji temple.
